messageBody:
On 16 Apr 2013, at 18:45, Jean-François Colson <jf@...> wrote:

>> True. So in some contexts you may have to make do with reading Shavian letters.
>
> That’s not fair.

Oh, come on. It's amazing that Shavian got encoded at all. There's no business case for it. There's not even a historical case for it like there is for Anatolian Hieroglyphs.

>> You will, orthographically. But I can't say that I believe that there is any chance whatsoever that the UCS will have both Shavian and Quikscript as two separate scripts.
>
> Why?

Because the main person in the UTC I've talked to already agrees that it makes sense to reduce the Roadmap allocation for QS extensions from 2 columns to 1 on the basis of my two code charts. There is a tiny chance that some of the font guys in the UTC will raise the issue that maybe they have diverged and are two scripts, but I don't believe that will happen.

>> Yes, that's right. But Quikscript isn't a separate script. It's a cursive variety of Shavian with some extensions. I'm sorry if this strikes you as unfortunate, but in the first place *I'm* not convinced, and even if I were, I can't think of any way that I could make a credible case to the UTC and WG2 about it.
>
> Couldn’t you try it?

Firstly you'd have to convince me.

> If it was accepted, that would be wonderful!
> If it was rejected, it would still be possible to propose a few extensions to the Shavian alphabet.

After twenty years at this work I've a reasonable idea what might be accepted.

Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com/
